snippet: El Faro, which disappeared in the Caribbean this month, was 40 years old, compared with an average of 11 years for the world’s commercial fleet.
abstract: Disappearance of 40-year-old American cargo ship El Faro in Caribbean has focused attention on problems that may arise as American merchant fleet ages; some point to century-old Merchant Marine Act as root of problem as it requires ships serving domestic routes to be built and registered in United States; there are few domestic shipyards that can build commercial-class ships, and labor costs associated with US-based production are exorbitant.
lead_paragraph: El Faro, which disappeared in the Caribbean this month, was 40 years old, compared with an average of 11 years for the world’s commercial fleet.

headline.print_headline: Missing Cargo Ship Highlights Vulnerability of Aging U.S. Fleet
headline.main: Missing Cargo Ship Highlights Vulnerability of Aging U.S. Fleet
